Let $z_1,\ldots,z_n\in \mathbb{C}$ be a sequence such that $z_1=1$. Suppose that the sequence of\[s_k=\sum_{1\leq i\leq n}z_i^k\]contains infinitely many $(n-1)$-tuples of consecutive values of $s_k$ which are all $0$. Then (essentially)\[z_j=e(j/n),\]where $e(x)=e^{2\pi ix}$.



A conjecture of Tur\'{a}n. Erd\H{o}s speculates that this may be true if there are two distinct $(n-1)$-tuples of consecutive values of $s_k$ which are $0$. He does not elaborate on what the 'essentially' may mean precisely.

This is true (in the stronger form with only two such tuples) - in fact if $n$ is odd then the $z_i$ must be exactly the $n$th roots of unity, and if $n$ is even they must be the vertices of two regular $(n/2)$-gons with the same circumscribed circle centred at the origin. This was first proved by Tijdeman \cite{Ti66}. An independent proof of this was given in the comments section by Hu, Tang, and Zhang.




References


[Ti66] Tijdeman, R., On a conjecture of {T}ur\'an and {E}rd\H{o}s. Indag. Math. (1966), 374--383.
